value: caption=Sunrise on the mountain Ruppberg near Zella-Mehlis (Thuringian Forest)

. Thuringia is one of the least known German states amongst foreign travelers but enjoys a good reputation with local vacationers. A predominantly mountainous and forested region, Thuringia is also known for a quartet of beautiful ancient cities and the Wartburg Castle - regarded by Germans as the most important castle in the country. Thuringia's boundaries are Bavaria (specifically Franconia) to the south and west, Saxony to the east, and the Bohemian forests of the Czech Republic to the east.

value: — town of the biggest university in Thuringia (and home to Goethe and Schiller, too)
— historic home of Johann Sebastian Bach, John A. Roebling (builder of the Brooklyn Bridge) and of the peasants' leader, Thomas
— site of Germany's largest folk music festival
— former capital of what is now the British royal family
The Hainich Forest - Germany's thirteenth national park with its magnificent tree-top walk
The Thuringian Forest - national park and winter sport centre

The most common language in Thuringia is German with its slight regional accent.

value: hours= Monday closed during winter, otherwise Mo-Tu 14:00-18:00, We-Su 12:00-18:00

The state of Thuringia is generally safe.  However, never leave your belongings such as wallets, luggage, and any other bags off you on the streets, where they might be stolen.  And the Polizei at the police station don't speak English well, so unless you or someone you are travelling with speaks German, they won't be too helpful even if you face trouble.
